title: 12 women sue school for the deaf alleging they were molested as students
text:
A dozen former students of a New York school for deaf children filed a lawsuit Wednesday arguing that they were abused by the male overseer of a female dormitory.

The New York Times reported that 12 women have sued the New York School for the Deaf, naming former housemaster Joseph Casucci and accusing him of sexually abusing girls in full view of other students as children were going to bed in the dormitory, which was arranged as a single room with rows of beds.

The Journal News reported that the abuse allegedly began when at least one victim was as young as four years old, and occurred over a a ten-year period between 1965 and 1975.

ADVERTISEMENT

“It was a nightly routine, and we were just little girls,’’ plaintiff Damita Jo Damiano told the Times. “It was the routine we would come to expect: We would do homework, take showers and the abuse would begin. It was normalized.”

At a press conference Wednesday, Damiano and another plaintiff described how they had no avenue to report their abuse to authorities.

"He abused all of us in our early childhood... That's a scar and trauma that stays with you," 59-year-old Marlene Hodge said, according to the Journal News. "We were little girls... We didn't know how to take care of something that needed [to be told]."

Many students feared speaking out to parents or family members due to difficulties in communication, the Times reported, resulting in the abuse going unreported for decades.

Attorneys for the school, referred to colloquially as Fanwood, did not respond to requests for comment from the Times and the school itself did immediately return The Hill's request for more information.
description: A dozen former students of a New York school for deaf children filed a lawsuit Wednesday arguing that they were abused by the male overseer of a female dormitory.
